intro: Ribes menziesii var. faustum, commonly known as the Pacific gooseberry, is a deciduous shrub native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Grossulariaceae family and is characterized by its erect growth habit and spiny stems. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish-green berries that are edible when ripe. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have serrated edges, contributing to its ornamental value. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in riparian zones and woodland edges.
